VOL. XV, NO. 23.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 20, 1911.

BOBBITT WINS FIRST PRIZE

DR. WELCH GREATLY HONORED

OUTDOOR PRACTICE BEGINS

Second Prize Is Awarded to Representative of Georgetown University.
Contest Well Attended.

The German Emperor Confers Prussian
Decoration on Him It Came
as a Great Surprise.

The Lacrosse Team Now Rounding Into
Shape Rapidly—Cripples Back
to Work This Week.

Last Friday evening McCoy Hall
was packed with an audience which
enjoyed a rare treat. Professor
Ritchey, of the Mount Wilson Observatory, delivered an illustrated
lecture on one of the most engrossing of subjects—the photography of
heavenly bodies. The entire lectnre
was presented in such a simple/and
lucid Manner that the explanations
of the complicated reflecting telescope and its parts presented no difficulties to the scientifically untrained mind. In order to show the
great effectiveness of the Mount
Wilson sixty-inch reflector, Professor Ritchey showed several series
of pictures of the same nebulx
taken by different telescopes. The
photographs taken by the Mount
Wilson telescope were so distinct
and detailed, and presented such a
contrast to the photographs taken
by other instruments, that the au-

On Thursday evening. March 16,
in M cCov Hall, was held the first
Maryland intercollegiate contest in
oratory. The speakers contesting
for prizes were Messrs. John F.
Crosby, of Georgetown University,
who spoke on "The United States
and the World Peace Movement";
L. Claude Bailey, of St. John's College, who spoke on -America and
Peace"; Lingurn Burkhead Bobbitt,
of Johns Hopkins University, who
spoke on "Patriotism and Peace,"
and Calvin Taylor Ryan, of Washington College, whose subject was
"The Practical Applications of Arbitration." The representative of
Loyola College, Mr. Charles Sebastian Lerch, whose intentions were to
speak upon "The Possibilities of
Peace,- was unable to appear by reason of the death of the rector of the
college.
The judges, who were Dr. Eugene A. Noble, Judge John J. Dobler, and Rev. Edwin B. Niver,
awarded the prizes as, follows:
First prize, $7;, to Mr. Bobbitt, and
the second prize,$50, to Mr. Crosby.
After the Hopkins Glee Club had
rendered the humorous "Mynheer
Van Dunk" and Dean Griffin had
made a few introductory remarks,
Dr. French, who was the presiding
officer, announced the rules of the
contest. Dr. French also made
known that the decoration, music,
arrangements, etc., were under the
supervision of the Johns Hopkins
Arbitration Society, and that the
prizes were offered through the Intercollegiate Peace Association by
the Maryland Peace Society.
Mr. Crosby, of Georgetown, was
first introduced, a speaker of imposing appearance, a pleasing personality and with a powerful, yet mellow,
voice.
The next speaker was Mr. Bailey,
of St. John's College. His delivery
was far inferior to that of his predecessor on the stage, being much too
rapid. But the subject matter of the
speech was commendable.
The next speaker introduced was
our own Mr. Bobbitt, whose address
was fully up to the standard expected by his friends. His speech
was to the effect that a country
should fear war, not as a result of
yellow journalism, but as a result of
patriotism. A nation ought to fight
only when it is attacked after having
offered peaceful settlements. Then,
and then only, is patriotism consistent with war.

Dr. William H. Welch has received one more distinction to bear
out the title of "the foremost exponent of medicine ,in the United
States," conferred by the leading
medical men of this nation. Emperor William of Germany has honored him with the decoration of the
Koeniglicher Kronen-Orden Zweiter Klasse. There are four distinct
classes in this order.
The decoration comes from Emperor William as King of Prussia,
and it is the emblem of a Prussian
order. Of gold and white, the decoration is in the form of a Maltese
cross, suspended from a blue ribbon. Upon one side is the crown of
Prussia in gold and on the other is
inscribed "Wilhelm, Konig."
Dr. Welch received the decoration Friday through the German
Ambassador at Washington, who
sent it to the German Consul in this
city, by whom it was presented in
person. Later a document will be
sent to Dr. Welch from the German
Government, which will formally
confer the distinction of the order.
"Of course, I would not find occasion to wear the decoration in this
country," said Dr. Welch. "The
only circumstances in all probability
under which I would pin it on
would be at some formal function
in Europe."
The decoration must be returned
to the Emperor upon the recipient's
death. That is always the condition upon which they are conferred.
It is not unreasonable, for were it
otherwise the decoratitins would
soon be scattered broadcast.
While Dr. Welch deprecates his
worthiness as a recipient of so signal a recognition by the German
Emperor, his many friends in Baltimore and the United States, who
are aware of the great work he has
accomplished for medicine, particularly in the science of pathology,
will by no means be at a loss to account for the tribute to his eminence.

The cold wave of last week prevented the lacrosse team from starting outdoor practice at Homewood.
With the first signs of•a let-up of
the cold weather, however, the
squad will begin outdoor work..
The men on the sick list are getting along fairly and will soon be
back at their old places. Johnny
Huck, who had his head laid open,
is almost well and he will be able
to play some time during the week.
Sears, who had his foot hurt, will
be back at goal by the end of the
week. Although Reaney Wolfe's
foot is not in a condition for him
to play on it at present, he will be
able to use it again in a short time.
The team will practice on the
regular field when it gets out to
Homewood. There are two other
fields, however, one of which the
baseball team will use. The other
one will not be used regularly. In
wet weather, when the good field is
too muddy to be used, the lacrosse
team will play on this vacant field—
the old Country School football
grounds.
The scrub team has elected Huck
manager. The team is in the Baltimore Lacrosse League, and will
have regular scheduled games during the spring. The other teams in
the league are the Baltimore City
College and the Mount Washitigton
Juniors. A cup will be given to the
winning team. As yet the schedule
is not complete, but Manager Huck
feels confident that this year's scrub
team will capture the trophy.
Coach Raleigh is still hard at
work with the Varsity team. The
attack men are beginning to show
a decided improvement. Their stick
work is improving and the attack is
more lively than it has been this
year. The defense is playing strong
and steady, and both the coach and
Captain Hulbert feel very much encouraged over the prospects.

FOOTBALL SCHEDULE COMPLETED
The

Hardest Schedule Any Hopkins
Team Ever Had—Three New
Teams Taken On.

At last the complete football
schedule has been given out. It
stands completed as follows:
October 7—Navy, at Annapolis.
October 14—Stevens, at Hoboken.
October 21—Maryland Agricultural College.
. October 28—Gettysbu rg.
November 4—Gallaudet.
November It—Virginia.
November t8—St. John's.
November 25—Carlisle.
November 3o—Western Maryland.
It is altogether the best schedule
a Hopkins football team has ever
had. The games with Navy, Virginia, and Carlisle will make the
fullest demand upon the strength of
the team. Gettysburg, the other
new team on the schedule, usually
puts out a powerful team, and they
will no doubt test the mettle of our
boys when they meet. The traditional first game with Maryland
Agricultural College has given
place to the Navy game. This will
no doubt be the hardest tussle of
the year, because it comes at a time
when our men will have had but
little practice, while the Navy will
be in fine trim, as the midshipmen
are always in training. But if the
Hopkins men get out to practice
two weeks before the University
opens, they can get into shape so
as to uphold the honor of the team.
.But it means work, work, work!

A Splendid Lecture on Astronomy.

The Turnbull Lecture 'Course on
Poetry begins today, at 5 o'clock, in
McCoy Halt. Cards of admission
will be required.

The two candidates for junior
class president at Wisconsin have
announced the respective platforms
upon which they will run for office.

Arbitration Society Meets.

The Arbitration Society held its
regular meeting last Wednesday
afternoon. Talks were given by
Messrs. White and 'Dickinson. Mr.
Dickinson gave a very interesting
discussion of Secretary Knox's plan
for the estabilshment of an international court of arbitral justice.
The next meeting is Wednesday,
March 29.
Harold L. Russell, '09, graduates
from the Yale Forestry School this
year.

THE NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 20, 1911
CALENDAR

SOPHOMORES OUT IN FORCE

WAGE-EARNERS AT COLUMBIA

Monday, March 20.

Captain Breuninger Holds First Basketball Practice Last Wednesday at
Central Y. M. C. A.

A Thousand Students at the New York
Institution Earn All or Part of

Ten men answered Captain Breuninger's call for candidates for the
sophomore basketball team. Manager L. L. Jacobs has arranged for
the sophomores to use the Central
Y. M. C. A. gymnasium for practice. Besides the ten who showed
up at the first practice, five or six
others are expected to join the
squad.
Captain Breuninger divided his
squad into two evenly matched
quintets, and they played a hard,
fast game for about three-quarters
of an hour. One of the best players in the sophomore squad is Sigmund, the crack center of the West
Branch Y. M. C. A.. Gillet and
Breuninger made many goals. for
their side. Melamet, the husky candidate for guard, showed up very
well on the defense. Ober, a former
Washington Preparatory School
star, is a good, all-around player.
Getz.and Tull are two other likely
candidates for guard positions.
The sophomores will practice two
or three times a week at the Y. M.
C. A. in addition to the practice they
will get in the upper-class league
games in the Hopkins gymnasium.
tanager Jacobs will try to schedule games with City College,
Friends' School and some other
strong secondary school quintets.
The basketball league is now running smoothly. The teams are very
evenly matched, and therefore the
games are full of excitement and
pleasure for the players. Stollenwerck is playing on No. VI team.
He shows that football isn't the
only game he can play, for he shot
nine goals for his team on Thursday. Dr. Magoffin was missed very
much by his team on Thursday, and
as a consequence his team lost.
There are three teams now tied for
first place. The league now stands:

More than $166,000 was earned
by the students of Columbia University in the last scholastic year.
The increase over student earnings
of a year ago is more than $6o,000,
while the number of students registered with the committee was
practically the same as in the preceding year.
The graduate students reported
the largest earnings, with a total of
$49,288.08 in the college year and
$11,479.47 in the summer vacation.
Students in the law school came
next, with $15,830.38 in the academic year and $10,486.12 in the
summer. The earnings for other
divisions of the university were:
College, $15,521.21 in the school
year and $9,333.95 in the summer;
science schools, $6,853.74 and $8,113.99: medicine, $5,256 and $2,344.90: fine arts, $3,223.18 and
$471 ; Teachers' College, $16,720.93
and $7,568.69; Batnard College,
$2,791.37 and $1,463.48. The average earnings in the respective
schools were in both winter and
summer: College, $355.02; applied
science, $325.25; medicine, $607.42;
law, $326.32; graduate faculties,
$784.20: fine arts, $578.40; Teachers' College, $684.90; Barnard College, $276.43.
In the summer vacation one Barnard girl got $432 as an investigator, while one student in the
graduate schools earned $8.52 as a
preacher. Most of the students,
however, sought out teaching and
tutors' positions, more than $85,000
being earned in that way.

THE NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 20, 1911

COMMUNICATIONS

LECTURE BY DR. SHOREY

(THE NEWS-LETTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length
upon topics of interest in the University
circles. Alumni especially are urged to
make use of this column.)

Review of Athens Fin du Siecle Charms
Auditors—Brilliant Talk Last
Tuesday Afternoon.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
There has been some discussion
in THE NEWS-LETTER recently in
regard to medical attendance. It is
quite my opinion that something
should be done in the matter of provision for medical attendance to
students. This is especially true in
the case of an institution like the
Hopkins, where, to the student,
every cent counts. With the facilities at hand, and the relations with
the medical faculties, there seems
to me no reason which may preclude
the possibility of providing for this
need. In view of the contemplated
move to Homewood and the change
to the dormitory system, such a
need will be felt all the more
strongly.
For a small additional sum from
each student, which would secure a
health insurance to everyone, a sufficient sum could be raised to provide
proper attendance.
In my own college such a system
was employed. The college owned
a handsomely equipped infirmary,
and for the sum of two or three
dollars from each student, paid at
the first of each academic year,
every medical attendance was furnished without further charge, save
for medicines or special nurses. A
regular trained nurse, employed by
the college, was in attendance.
To me it seems that it Would be a
pleasure for each student to pay
such a fee, thus feeling sure of
himself in case of financial stringency, which is usually the case
with students, needless to say.
This question should be put up
squarely to the proper authorities
and be dealt with so as to secure
the greatest possible benefit for the
students.
Your agitation of so important a
matter is quite commendable. P.
To the Editor of

A meeting for the organization
of a Hopkins tennis team will be

No steps were taken at the regular quarterly meeting of the trustees of Princeton University toward
filling the presidency left vacant by
the resignation of Gov. Woodrow
Wilson.
The Harvard University catalogue this year shows a total enrollment of 6,279 students, a decrease
of twenty-nine from last year's figures.

A lecture which-was undoubtedly
one of the most deliffhtful ever delivered before the University was
given last Tuesday afternoon by
Paul Shorey, professor of Greek in
the University of Chicago. Professor Shorey spoke upon "Athens Fin
du Siècle"—Athens at that decadent, yet still brilliant period of
her history, which followed upon
her defeat by Sparta and preceded
her degradation at the hands of
Macedon. The lecturer by his insight, wit, and appreciation made
the period live again before his audience : its social life, its politics,
and its literature; its care-free license, its gilded corruption, and its
tinseled ostentation. He did not
dignify his theme with a pompous
and analytical dissertation, but
adapted the tone of his paper to its
subject; and by his apt use of modern slang and modern allusions
charmed his hearers into the belief
that they had supped with Lycoris,
bartered with Demosthenes, and applauded a play of Menander.
Dr. Shorey is one of the most
cultured and brilliant of modern
classical scholars. His "literary"
edition of Horace's Odes, as he calls
it, is already well known to some of
us. More recently he has published
"The Case for the Classics," an eloquent and incontrovertible argument
in favor of the continuance of classical studies.
At the suggestion of President
Lowell a university chorus was
formed at Harvard, for which fifty
candidates applied.

BOBBITT WINS FIRST PRIZE

DR. WELCH GREATLY HONORED

OUTDOOR PRACTICE BEGINS

Second Prize Is Awarded to Representative of Georgetown University.
Contest Well Attended.

The German Emperor Confers Prussian
Decoration on Him It Came
as a Great Surprise.

The Lacrosse Team Now Rounding Into
Shape Rapidly—Cripples Back
to Work This Week.

Last Friday evening McCoy Hall
was packed with an audience which
enjoyed a rare treat. Professor
Ritchey, of the Mount Wilson Observatory, delivered an illustrated
lecture on one of the most engrossing of subjects—the photography of
heavenly bodies. The entire lectnre
was presented in such a simple/and
lucid Manner that the explanations
of the complicated reflecting telescope and its parts presented no difficulties to the scientifically untrained mind. In order to show the
great effectiveness of the Mount
Wilson sixty-inch reflector, Professor Ritchey showed several series
of pictures of the same nebulx
taken by different telescopes. The
photographs taken by the Mount
Wilson telescope were so distinct
and detailed, and presented such a
contrast to the photographs taken
by other instruments, that the au-

On Thursday evening. March 16,
in M cCov Hall, was held the first
Maryland intercollegiate contest in
oratory. The speakers contesting
for prizes were Messrs. John F.
Crosby, of Georgetown University,
who spoke on "The United States
and the World Peace Movement";
L. Claude Bailey, of St. John's College, who spoke on -America and
Peace"; Lingurn Burkhead Bobbitt,
of Johns Hopkins University, who
spoke on "Patriotism and Peace,"
and Calvin Taylor Ryan, of Washington College, whose subject was
"The Practical Applications of Arbitration." The representative of
Loyola College, Mr. Charles Sebastian Lerch, whose intentions were to
speak upon "The Possibilities of
Peace,- was unable to appear by reason of the death of the rector of the
college.
The judges, who were Dr. Eugene A. Noble, Judge John J. Dobler, and Rev. Edwin B. Niver,
awarded the prizes as, follows:
First prize, $7;, to Mr. Bobbitt, and
the second prize,$50, to Mr. Crosby.
After the Hopkins Glee Club had
rendered the humorous "Mynheer
Van Dunk" and Dean Griffin had
made a few introductory remarks,
Dr. French, who was the presiding
officer, announced the rules of the
contest. Dr. French also made
known that the decoration, music,
arrangements, etc., were under the
supervision of the Johns Hopkins
Arbitration Society, and that the
prizes were offered through the Intercollegiate Peace Association by
the Maryland Peace Society.
Mr. Crosby, of Georgetown, was
first introduced, a speaker of imposing appearance, a pleasing personality and with a powerful, yet mellow,
voice.
The next speaker was Mr. Bailey,
of St. John's College. His delivery
was far inferior to that of his predecessor on the stage, being much too
rapid. But the subject matter of the
speech was commendable.
The next speaker introduced was
our own Mr. Bobbitt, whose address
was fully up to the standard expected by his friends. His speech
was to the effect that a country
should fear war, not as a result of
yellow journalism, but as a result of
patriotism. A nation ought to fight
only when it is attacked after having
offered peaceful settlements. Then,
and then only, is patriotism consistent with war.

Dr. William H. Welch has received one more distinction to bear
out the title of "the foremost exponent of medicine ,in the United
States," conferred by the leading
medical men of this nation. Emperor William of Germany has honored him with the decoration of the
Koeniglicher Kronen-Orden Zweiter Klasse. There are four distinct
classes in this order.
The decoration comes from Emperor William as King of Prussia,
and it is the emblem of a Prussian
order. Of gold and white, the decoration is in the form of a Maltese
cross, suspended from a blue ribbon. Upon one side is the crown of
Prussia in gold and on the other is
inscribed "Wilhelm, Konig."
Dr. Welch received the decoration Friday through the German
Ambassador at Washington, who
sent it to the German Consul in this
city, by whom it was presented in
person. Later a document will be
sent to Dr. Welch from the German
Government, which will formally
confer the distinction of the order.
"Of course, I would not find occasion to wear the decoration in this
country," said Dr. Welch. "The
only circumstances in all probability
under which I would pin it on
would be at some formal function
in Europe."
The decoration must be returned
to the Emperor upon the recipient's
death. That is always the condition upon which they are conferred.
It is not unreasonable, for were it
otherwise the decoratitins would
soon be scattered broadcast.
While Dr. Welch deprecates his
worthiness as a recipient of so signal a recognition by the German
Emperor, his many friends in Baltimore and the United States, who
are aware of the great work he has
accomplished for medicine, particularly in the science of pathology,
will by no means be at a loss to account for the tribute to his eminence.

The cold wave of last week prevented the lacrosse team from starting outdoor practice at Homewood.
With the first signs of•a let-up of
the cold weather, however, the
squad will begin outdoor work..
The men on the sick list are getting along fairly and will soon be
back at their old places. Johnny
Huck, who had his head laid open,
is almost well and he will be able
to play some time during the week.
Sears, who had his foot hurt, will
be back at goal by the end of the
week. Although Reaney Wolfe's
foot is not in a condition for him
to play on it at present, he will be
able to use it again in a short time.
The team will practice on the
regular field when it gets out to
Homewood. There are two other
fields, however, one of which the
baseball team will use. The other
one will not be used regularly. In
wet weather, when the good field is
too muddy to be used, the lacrosse
team will play on this vacant field—
the old Country School football
grounds.
The scrub team has elected Huck
manager. The team is in the Baltimore Lacrosse League, and will
have regular scheduled games during the spring. The other teams in
the league are the Baltimore City
College and the Mount Washitigton
Juniors. A cup will be given to the
winning team. As yet the schedule
is not complete, but Manager Huck
feels confident that this year's scrub
team will capture the trophy.
Coach Raleigh is still hard at
work with the Varsity team. The
attack men are beginning to show
a decided improvement. Their stick
work is improving and the attack is
more lively than it has been this
year. The defense is playing strong
and steady, and both the coach and
Captain Hulbert feel very much encouraged over the prospects.

FOOTBALL SCHEDULE COMPLETED
The

Hardest Schedule Any Hopkins
Team Ever Had—Three New
Teams Taken On.

At last the complete football
schedule has been given out. It
stands completed as follows:
October 7—Navy, at Annapolis.
October 14—Stevens, at Hoboken.
October 21—Maryland Agricultural College.
. October 28—Gettysbu rg.
November 4—Gallaudet.
November It—Virginia.
November t8—St. John's.
November 25—Carlisle.
November 3o—Western Maryland.
It is altogether the best schedule
a Hopkins football team has ever
had. The games with Navy, Virginia, and Carlisle will make the
fullest demand upon the strength of
the team. Gettysburg, the other
new team on the schedule, usually
puts out a powerful team, and they
will no doubt test the mettle of our
boys when they meet. The traditional first game with Maryland
Agricultural College has given
place to the Navy game. This will
no doubt be the hardest tussle of
the year, because it comes at a time
when our men will have had but
little practice, while the Navy will
be in fine trim, as the midshipmen
are always in training. But if the
Hopkins men get out to practice

CALENDAR

SOPHOMORES OUT IN FORCE

WAGE-EARNERS AT COLUMBIA

Monday, March 20.

Captain Breuninger Holds First Basketball Practice Last Wednesday at
Central Y. M. C. A.

A Thousand Students at the New York
Institution Earn All or Part of

Ten men answered Captain Breuninger's call for candidates for the
sophomore basketball team. Manager L. L. Jacobs has arranged for
the sophomores to use the Central
Y. M. C. A. gymnasium for practice. Besides the ten who showed
up at the first practice, five or six
others are expected to join the
squad.
Captain Breuninger divided his
squad into two evenly matched
quintets, and they played a hard,
fast game for about three-quarters
of an hour. One of the best players in the sophomore squad is Sigmund, the crack center of the West
Branch Y. M. C. A.. Gillet and
Breuninger made many goals. for
their side. Melamet, the husky candidate for guard, showed up very
well on the defense. Ober, a former
Washington Preparatory School
star, is a good, all-around player.
Getz.and Tull are two other likely
candidates for guard positions.
The sophomores will practice two
or three times a week at the Y. M.
C. A. in addition to the practice they
will get in the upper-class league
games in the Hopkins gymnasium.
tanager Jacobs will try to schedule games with City College,
Friends' School and some other
strong secondary school quintets.
The basketball league is now running smoothly. The teams are very
evenly matched, and therefore the
games are full of excitement and
pleasure for the players. Stollenwerck is playing on No. VI team.
He shows that football isn't the
only game he can play, for he shot
nine goals for his team on Thursday. Dr. Magoffin was missed very
much by his team on Thursday, and
as a consequence his team lost.
There are three teams now tied for
first place. The league now stands:

More than $166,000 was earned
by the students of Columbia University in the last scholastic year.
The increase over student earnings
of a year ago is more than $6o,000,
while the number of students registered with the committee was
practically the same as in the preceding year.
The graduate students reported
the largest earnings, with a total of
$49,288.08 in the college year and
$11,479.47 in the summer vacation.
Students in the law school came
next, with $15,830.38 in the academic year and $10,486.12 in the
summer. The earnings for other
divisions of the university were:
College, $15,521.21 in the school
year and $9,333.95 in the summer;
science schools, $6,853.74 and $8,113.99: medicine, $5,256 and $2,344.90: fine arts, $3,223.18 and
$471 ; Teachers' College, $16,720.93
and $7,568.69; Batnard College,
$2,791.37 and $1,463.48. The average earnings in the respective
schools were in both winter and
summer: College, $355.02; applied
science, $325.25; medicine, $607.42;
law, $326.32; graduate faculties,
$784.20: fine arts, $578.40; Teachers' College, $684.90; Barnard College, $276.43.
In the summer vacation one Barnard girl got $432 as an investigator, while one student in the
graduate schools earned $8.52 as a
preacher. Most of the students,
however, sought out teaching and
tutors' positions, more than $85,000
being earned in that way.

THE NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 20, 1911

COMMUNICATIONS

LECTURE BY DR. SHOREY

(THE NEWS-LETTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length
upon topics of interest in the University
circles. Alumni especially are urged to
make use of this column.)

Review of Athens Fin du Siecle Charms
Auditors—Brilliant Talk Last
Tuesday Afternoon.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
There has been some discussion
in THE NEWS-LETTER recently in
regard to medical attendance. It is
quite my opinion that something
should be done in the matter of provision for medical attendance to
students. This is especially true in
the case of an institution like the
Hopkins, where, to the student,
every cent counts. With the facilities at hand, and the relations with
the medical faculties, there seems
to me no reason which may preclude
the possibility of providing for this
need. In view of the contemplated
move to Homewood and the change
to the dormitory system, such a
need will be felt all the more
strongly.
For a small additional sum from
each student, which would secure a
health insurance to everyone, a sufficient sum could be raised to provide
proper attendance.
In my own college such a system
was employed. The college owned
a handsomely equipped infirmary,
and for the sum of two or three
dollars from each student, paid at
the first of each academic year,
every medical attendance was furnished without further charge, save
for medicines or special nurses. A
regular trained nurse, employed by
the college, was in attendance.
To me it seems that it Would be a
pleasure for each student to pay
such a fee, thus feeling sure of
himself in case of financial stringency, which is usually the case
with students, needless to say.
This question should be put up
squarely to the proper authorities
and be dealt with so as to secure
the greatest possible benefit for the
students.
Your agitation of so important a
matter is quite commendable. P.
To the Editor of

•0

Notice.

A meeting for the organization
of a Hopkins tennis team will be
held in the trophy room, at
o'clock, Tuesday, of this week.
No steps were taken at the regular quarterly meeting of the trustees of Princeton University toward
filling the presidency left vacant by
the resignation of Gov. Woodrow
Wilson.
The Harvard University catalogue this year shows a total enrollment of 6,279 students, a decrease
of twenty-nine from last year's figures.

A lecture which-was undoubtedly
one of the most deliffhtful ever delivered before the University was
given last Tuesday afternoon by
Paul Shorey, professor of Greek in
the University of Chicago. Professor Shorey spoke upon "Athens Fin
du Siècle"—Athens at that decadent, yet still brilliant period of
her history, which followed upon
her defeat by Sparta and preceded
her degradation at the hands of
Macedon. The lecturer by his insight, wit, and appreciation made
the period live again before his audience : its social life, its politics,
and its literature; its care-free license, its gilded corruption, and its
tinseled ostentation. He did not
dignify his theme with a pompous
and analytical dissertation, but
adapted the tone of his paper to its
subject; and by his apt use of modern slang and modern allusions
charmed his hearers into the belief
that they had supped with Lycoris,
bartered with Demosthenes, and applauded a play of Menander.
Dr. Shorey is one of the most
cultured and brilliant of modern
classical scholars. His "literary"
edition of Horace's Odes, as he calls
it, is already well known to some of
us. More recently he has published
